item.title: Israel and Iran stay largely silent after limited retaliatory strike
item.description: A person familiar with the situation told NBC News that Israel carried out an operation in Iran. Earlier, Israeli officials notified U.S. officials that a response was coming.

media:content.media:text: A man walks past a banner depicting missiles along a street in Tehran
media:content.media:description: A man walks past a banner depicting missiles along a street in Tehran on April 19, 2024.

item.title: House tees up votes on Ukraine and Israel aid as Speaker Johnson defies his right flank
item.dc:creator: Sahil Kapur and Rebecca Kaplan and Kyle Stewart and Lori Rampani and Syedah Asghar
item.description: The House advanced four separate bills, including aid for Ukraine and Israel after months of delay and a bill that could ban TikTok in the U.S.

media:content.media:text: Mike Johnson
media:content.media:description: Mike Johnson on April 17, 2024 in Washington, D.C.

item.title: New exhibit in New York re-creates Israeli music festival attacked on Oct. 7
item.dc:creator: Daniel Arkin and Chloe Melas
item.description: The objects bear the scars of a massacre.

media:content.media:text: Nova Exhibition Installation
media:content.media:description: Nova survivor Natalie Sanandaji and Reef Peretz, chairman of the Nova Foundation, look at destroyed cars taken from the Nova festival on display in New York City.

media:content.media:text: Nova Exhibition Installation

media:content.media:text: Nova Exhibition Installation
media:content.media:description: Camping items taken from the festival re-create the festival layout.

item.title: Class destroyed: A look at what has become of Gaza's revered universities
item.dc:creator: Chantal Da Silva and Yasmine Salam and Matthew Mulligan and Bianca Britton
item.description: Built over decades, Gaza’s universities embodied the ambitions of young Palestinians. In weeks, the Israeli military destroyed them.

item.title: She secretly educated herself to escape Afghanistan. Now, she's working to help women still there
item.dc:creator: Maya Eaglin
item.description: Sola Mahfouz stopped going to school in 2007 when she was an 11-year-old living in Afghanistan.

item.title: Meet the families who've taken children as young as 2 to Everest Base Camp
item.dc:creator: Aria Bendix
item.description: A handful of families have taken children as young as 2 years old to Mount Everest Base Camp in recent years. Three of them describe the experience.

item.title: Looking for leads, not love: Job seekers in China turn Tinder into a networking tool
item.dc:creator: Larissa Gao and Helen Chen
item.description: Young people in China facing an increasingly tough labor market are turning to an unlikely place for help in their job searches: Tinder.

media:content.media:text: Photo Illustration: A man's Tinder profile reads "Looking for Full-tim employment"
media:content.media:description: Some young people in China see Tinder as a way to find potential job leads.

media:content.media:text: China Youth Unemployment
media:content.media:description: University students at a job fair in Wuhan, China, in March.

item.title: Almost one billion people start voting in India's general election
item.description: A substantial number of Indians voted in the first phase of the world's largest election, authorities said, as Prime Minister Narendra Modi seeks a third term on the back of issues such as growth, welfare and Hindu nationalism. NBC News' Janis Mackey Frayer reports on India's democratic choice.

media:content.media:title: Almost one billion people start voting in India's general election
media:content.media:description: A substantial number of Indians voted in the first phase of the world's largest election, authorities said, as Prime Minister Narendra Modi seeks a third term on the back of issues such as growth, welfare and Hindu nationalism. NBC News' Janis Mackey Frayer reports on India's democratic choice.

item.title: U.S. not involved in any offensive operations, Blinken says of Israel's strike on Iran
item.description: Speaking after a meeting of G7 ministers in Capri, Italy, U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken had little to say about Israel's strike on Iran other than to say the U.S. was not involved in any offensive operations and that Washington and its allies were working to de-escalate tensions in the Middle East.

media:content.media:title: U.S. not involved in any offensive operations, Blinken says of Israel's strike on Iran
media:content.media:description: Speaking after a meeting of G7 ministers in Capri, Italy, U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken had little to say about Israel's strike on Iran other than to say the U.S. was not involved in any offensive operations and that Washington and its allies were working to de-escalate tensions in the Middle East.

item.title: Middle East on edge after Israel launches strike inside Iran
item.description: Israel attacked Iran with a limited strike, a move that is threatening to escalate tensions between the two countries. Explosions were reported in the skies of two Iranian cities, Isfahan and Tabriz. NBC News' Raf Sanchez reports on the latest developments in the Israel-Iran conflict.

media:content.media:title: Middle East on edge after Israel launches strike inside Iran
media:content.media:description: Israel attacked Iran with a limited strike, a move that is threatening to escalate tensions between the two countries. Explosions were reported in the skies of two Iranian cities, Isfahan and Tabriz. NBC News' Raf Sanchez reports on the latest developments in the Israel-Iran conflict.

item.title: IAEA chief says Iran could produce a nuclear weapon 'within months'
item.description: Rafael Grossi, director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, spoke with Sky News' Wilfred Frost in the wake of Israel's strike on Isfahan. “Sky News Today with Wilfred Frost” streams live daily at 5 a.m. ET on NBC News NOW.

media:content.media:title: IAEA chief says Iran could produce a nuclear weapon 'within months'
media:content.media:description: Rafael Grossi, director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, spoke with Sky News' Wilfred Frost in the wake of Israel's strike on Isfahan. “Sky News Today with Wilfred Frost” streams live daily at 5 a.m. ET on NBC News NOW.

item.title: Chinese runner’s win is revoked after investigation into Beijing Half Marathon
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: The results of Beijing’s half marathon were canceled after an investigation found that three African runners had slowed down to allow a Chinese athlete to win.

media:content.media:text: Half-marathon in Beijing
media:content.media:description: From left, Willy Mnangat and Robert Keter of Kenya, He Jie of China and Dejene Hailu Bikila of Ethiopia approach the finish line in the Beijing Half Marathon on Sunday.

item.title: Woman who sent Harry Styles 8,000 cards in a month sentenced to 14 weeks in jail for stalking
item.dc:creator: Patrick Smith and David K. Li and Meriam Bouarrouj
item.description: A 35-year-old woman who sent 8,000 greeting cards in one month to Harry Styles admitted to stalking the pop superstar and was sentenced to 14 weeks behind bars.

media:content.media:text: Harry Styles
media:content.media:description: Harry Styles in 2022.

item.title: U.S. deports about 50 Haitians to nation hit with gang violence, ending monthslong pause in flights
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: The Biden administration sent about 50 Haitians back to their country on Thursday marking the first deportation flight in several months to the nation struggling with gang violence.

media:content.media:text: Armed police officers monitor a street
media:content.media:description: Police officers monitor a street after gang violence in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, last month.

item.title: Nearly half of China's major cities are sinking, researchers say
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Nearly half of China’s major cities are suffering “moderate to severe” levels of subsidence, putting millions of people at risk of flooding, a study found.

media:content.media:text: Members of the Peoples Armed Police wade through receding floodwaters as they help to retrieve goods from a building in Zhuozhou, China
media:content.media:description: Members of the People’s Armed Police wading through receding floodwaters in Zhuozhou, China, last year.

item.title: Ecuador's President Noboa looks set to win vote on new security measures
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Ecuador’s President Daniel Noboa looks set to win a referendum on Sunday that asks voters to support new security measures to fight rising violence, although recent power cuts could pose a threat to the ‘yes’ vote.

media:content.media:text: Daniel Noboa in Madrid
media:content.media:description: Pres. Daniel Noboa is asking voters on Sunday to approve new measures as the country grapples with rising violence and the rise of cocaine-smuggling gangs.

item.title: Brazil’s President Lula creates two new Indigenous territories, bringing total to 10
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva on Thursday announced the creation of two new Indigenous territories for Brazil, bringing the total number of new reserves during this term to 10.

media:content.media:text: Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva and Minister of Indigenous Peoples Sonia Guajajara arrive at the closing ceremony of the 1st Ordinary Meeting of the National Council for Indigenous Policy
media:content.media:description: Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva and Minister of Indigenous Peoples Sonia Guajajara arrive Thursday at the closing ceremony of the 1st Ordinary Meeting of the National Council for Indigenous Policy in Brasilia.

item.title: Apple pulls WhatsApp and Threads from China app store after Beijing order
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Apple said on Friday it had removed Meta Platforms’ WhatsApp and Threads from its App Store in China after being ordered to do so by the Chinese government, which cited national security concerns.

media:content.media:text: Apple Store in Shanghai
media:content.media:description: Tourists outside an Apple store in Shanghai, China, on April 11.

item.title: Catholic Church in communist Cuba proposes an open dialogue with the government
item.dc:creator: Orlando Matos and Carmen Sesin
item.description: In an interview with NBC News, the assistant secretary of the Conference of Catholic Bishops of Cuba is proposing a national dialogue to help resolve the economic crisis that has gripped the island.

media:content.media:text: Father Ariel Suárez
media:content.media:description: Father Ariel Suárez, assistant secretary of the Conference of Catholic Bishops of Cuba speaks with NBC News on April 18, 2024.

item.title: Man suspected of aiding Zelenskyy assassination plot arrested in Poland
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: A Polish man has been arrested on allegations of being ready to help Russia in an alleged plot to assassinate Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

media:content.media:text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy arrived in Paris to sign a bilateral security agreement with France hours after he officialized a similar one with Germany.
media:content.media:description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in Paris in February.

item.title: Scotland pauses prescriptions of puberty blockers for transgender minors
item.dc:creator: Matt Lavietes
item.description: Scotland’s sole clinic for treating transgender youths announced Thursday that it is pausing new prescriptions of puberty blockers for minors.

media:content.media:text: Trans rights activists attend a protest in London
media:content.media:description: Trans rights activists attend a protest in London on Jan. 21, 2023.

item.title: Suspected Iran spy ship sails home as the world awaits a new Israeli attack
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mulligan
item.description: Suspected Iranian spy ship MV Behshad is sailing home — a move that comes as the world awaits Israel’s response to Tehran’s retaliatory attack.

media:content.media:text: Quds Day Rally In Tehran, Iran
media:content.media:description: An Iranian flag flies in downtown Tehran on April 14, 2023.

item.title: Germany arrests men accused of spying on U.S. military sites for Russia in sabotage plot to undermine Ukraine aid
item.dc:creator: Carlo Angerer and Patrick Smith and The Associated Press and Yuliya Talmazan
item.description: Two arrested in Germany on suspicion of spying for Russia and collecting information on targets including U.S. military facilities to undermine Ukraine aid, authorities said Thursday.

media:content.media:text: Germany arrests men who allegedly spied on U.S. military sites for Russia in sabotage plot to undermine Ukraine aid
media:content.media:description: Ukraine has long warned that Russian spies were active across Europe.

item.title: Prince Harry now officially considers the U.S. — not Britain — his primary residence
item.dc:creator: Patrick Smith
item.description: Prince Harry now officially considers himself a resident of the United States, according to a new U.K. regulatory filing.

media:content.media:text: Britain's Prince Harry participates in the Royal Salute Polo Challenge, in Wellington
media:content.media:description: Prince Harry and Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, moved to the U.S. in 2020.
